Despite the false narrative of trump and the republicans, as I have been writing on Seeking Alpha for a few years now: we live in a "New Age of Energy Abundance" and the U.S. is energy independent (by an estimated ~3 million boe/d) and is the #1 petroleum producer on the planet and the #1 LNG exporter on the planet. This is one reason the XLE Energy ETF is one of the worst performing sector ETFs over the past decade (if not the worst ...) and if it wasn't for Putin & Netanyahu's wars, the results would have been even worst, and likely significantly so. Meantime, note the American "big-3" (Exxon, Chevron, ConocoPhillips) aren't making any significant investments in wind, solar, and battery backup capacity. As a result, they are increasingly ill-prepared for the 21st Century of electrification and they are increasingly contributing to global warming, and we saw the results of that with the horrific recent hurricane that laid waste to so much of the Southeastern U.S. and took more than 100 lives.There is no way the planet will stop burning up as long as the "Big-3" (little 3?) refused to invest some of their cash-flow directly into renewables. Further, the supposed "carbon sequestration" is a total disaster, ineffective, and waste of time, money, and resources. What a world!

Any dilution is the subject of the acquisition....not the secondary offering where the opposite happened.

Imo it's only dilution if it does not add equal value, given the history of this company so far I expect it to add more than equal value to the company. I also expect with the drop in share price the company will be using the variable dividend pool to buy shares back this quarter if it still could.

@lithops In theory even the issuing 10% new share to executives every year needn’t be value dilutive if the executives actually add that much value or if they would have been paid that much in cash otherwise.  Those are very, very rebuttable presumptions though!
@houtex Yes, there's certainly a big difference between dilution like this, and a tech company issuing 10% new shares to its executives every year.  And REIT issuances seem a lot different too.

@lithops Different people have different definitions of “dilution” as you highlight. I really wish people would add a word to help clarify. Ownership dilution doesn’t mean value dilution or EPS dilution or CFPS dilution etc. I blame WallStreetBets. That’s where I first saw this focus on “they issued shares it’s dilution!”.  Corporations and finance professionals don’t care about the number of shares. They care about the value each of those shares.

Certainly seems like a good acquisition.  However, dilution refers to the original shareholders having a lower percentage share of a company after a stock issuance, so it has occurred here whether or not earnings and cash flow per share increase.
